reviewText: A very detailed look at Hitler's rise from a German perspective.  Focuses less on the war than the rise to political power.  Lots of rare footage. Highly recommended.

reviewText: I saw this movie for the first time upon its release in 1977 in a theatre in Germany. I've seen it subsequently in VHS format and was decidedly disappointed in the quality. However, this DVD version is as crisp as the original theatrical release, and the audio remains excellent. The entire quality of this version is really commendable. It's impossible to do justice to Hitler's career in two and half hours, but Fest's film remains the standard by which other Fuehrer documentaries must be judged. To its credit, the film focuses on Hitler's early rise to power, and there's great film from the 1927-1932 era. The period of 1933-39 is also strong, though the WWII years as a little hurried. A weakness is that few of Hitler's personal relationships are exlored, either with his various girlfriends or with the Nazi hierarchy.There has been more early film of Hitler unearthed since this film was released, but they include an abundance of rare material that is not found elsewhere. The background music is not grating and the narrator is pleasing. There are also very few factual errors contained in this film. I highly recommend it, it's held up beautifully in the past 25 years.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It would seem that the producers of this doc. wrote mostly the positives and not dwell on the negatives of his rule.  Without embellishment and almost feverish preoccupation with the pomp and ceremonies of Nazism; this might have been a much better analysis.  It seems to idolize Der Fuhrer without a deeper explication of the mystical aspects of Hitler's SS and inner circle of adherents.  Without that the enigma of Hitler cannot be understood and perhaps even today those who detail the more obvious facts of his rise do not themselves understand the diabolical nuances of that belief system.  There was no mention of the special archaeological searches and digs conducted by Reich scientists.  Nor did it explain his theory of Aryan Supremacy based on Sumerian culture.  Neither it cover the search for explanations about who engineered Indus cultures.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film documentary started out strange with the unusual credits at the beginning, but once it started into the narration and rolling the images and footage, it held my attention and interest the whole duration.  It's a good way to see how Hitler gradually came to power, the influences that shaped his warped world-view and then how he completely blew the whole thing by trying to grab all of Europe in a matter of a few years.... crazy. What's most startling to ponder after seeing this is to think how a whole population could be so blind to this madness and whipped up into a frenzy of allegiance to this guy in the name of national pride.  Really a study in someone who is a master of oration, timing, and very persuasive and effective propaganda... see it, and look around you today and imagine some of the same behavior in our midst.  Not hard to see how 'sheeple' today blindly follow on some notion or stance that drives people to appose other people.
summary: Excellent.  Great footage! Great Narration! Hitler in a nutshell from beginning to end.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The main focus of this documentary is a study of Hitler and his ability to influence the German people. The original footage includes film and photos recorded at Hitler's request. I would choose to disagree that the narrative is 'pathetic.' It is well presented and the information is reasonably accurate. Remember that the narration is intended to emphasize the prevailing attitudes during this timeline. The overview is a psychological profile of the multifaceted traits that offer an explanation of who Hitler was and what he accomplished.  It is easy to follow and well organized. Hitler's own study of the footage offers an insight to his use of words and mannerisms combined for maximum effect on those in his audience.  The Teutonic myth of Aryan supremacy and it's origins is addressed. Without being boring or tedious, this presents information and original footage that isn't usually presented in documentaries. Recommended for those with an interest in WWII military history and those interested in Hitler as a person and leader of Nazi Germany.  Well worth watching!
summary: A psychological profile  . . . interesting original footage!

reviewText: This film is a helpful tool we can use to try to understand how people were willing to give up their freedoms during an economically difficult time in their history. This is an example of nationalism run rampant while using a minority of the population as scapegoats in order to gain political power. Watch and learn.

reviewText: This is an interesting documentary on Hitler's career since it is from a German perspective. The idea that Hitler was lazy is something I had not heard before. It puts less stress on the dissension in the German military than other videos. One area where it falls short is the video talks almost entirely abut the German Army and Air Force. You would almost think Germany did not have a Navy.

reviewText: Agree with Mr. Lassen's detailed review.  This is a great documentary, well executed, and with great use of lots of archive footage...some of it rare.  This was previously available on DVD from a small company at a much higher price...glad to see that it has now been picked up by a more mainstream distributor.  More people should see this film to better understand the evil that men do.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This comprehensive documentary (it's 151 minutes) was created in 1977 and yet it is still one of the better pieces about Hitler specifically.  It's old school film making, a bit dry in presentation, but nevertheless effective at covering the different stages of Hitler's life.  Although portions can seem too simplistic and others rather slanted, it's hard to deny the overall impact that the film (with its effective use of archival footage) creates.  It basically breaks Hitler's career into three distinct stages which can be watched independently.  There is (1889-1933) his early years to his ascendency to Prime Minister, (1933-1939) his rule of Germany until the outbreak of WWII, and (1939-1945) the war until his death.  As this documentary is now 35 years old, it may not be as polished as more contemporary documentaries and the subject matter has been explored at length since then but, for its time, it was absolutely revelatory. KGHarris, 5/12.
summary: A Comprehensive Look At The Rise And Fall Of Hitler Shown In Three Historical Stages
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw this documentary in the 1990s on the Discovery Channel under the titleHitler: The Whole Story [VHS]. I bought the VHS version a few years ago since I could not find a DVD version of this great film. While doing some research on the VHS version again (I was hoping the DVD was finally released) I found out that the Discovery Channel had taken an old documentary from 1977 and put their stamp on it. After buying and viewing this DVD I am happy that this is the same version as the old Discovery Channel's and this one is even better since the Discovery Channel version never had subtitles during the German speaking parts. This version does!This documentary is more than just a film about Hitler. It is a film on Germany and the German people as well. Anyone with an interest in the period will appreciate this. I highly recommend it!I'd write more, but the other reviews should give you a good picture of what this film contains. I would also read reviews from the VHS versionHitler: The Whole Story [VHS].
summary: Old Documentary That Still Hits A Homerun!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The 1977 documentary Hitler: A career (original German: Hitler: Eine Karriere) is widely regarded as one of the best (and some would say the best) documentaries on that evil man. Written by Joachim C. Fest (who also authored the book Hitler, 1973 German, 1974 English), directed by Fest & Christian Herrendoerfer, and well narrated by British actor Stephen Murray, the 151-minute documentary offers an in-depth look (4:3 format in B&W;, with some color) at Hitler's rise to power and his consolidation of it during the 1930s. Although there are scenes of warfare, this is not stressed per se but rather used as a context for sociological, political, and military events.Extras on this excellent DVD are minimal: a photo gallery with pics sans date or context; ads for 12 other First-Run DVDs, including 3 trailers.I bought Hitler: A career (1977) in 6/08 and after watching it decided to view the 2003 TV movie Hitler: The rise of evil (2 DVDs), which I had purchased in 11/07. Image my surprise to find the complete documentary Hitler: A career as an extra on disk 2 of the movie Hitler: The rise of evil.Hitler - The Rise of EvilRECOMMENDATION: Do NOT buy Hitler: A career (1977), which has minimal extras as noted above. INSTEAD, buy Hitler: The rise of evil (2003), which not only has the movie but also the 1977 documentary. Although the movie DVD (Rise of evil) and documentary DVD (Career) list for the same price, used copies of Rise of evil are much less expensive than used DVDs of Career.
summary: Hitler: A career (1977) is an extra on the TV movie Hitler: The rise of evil (2003)
